results.description:
Uncover the power of a quieter mind and ensure the renewal of a healthier you through movement, breath, and meditation. I welcome each student to come escape the bustle of the city to experience above and find their inner guru in my  class!

WELCOME TO FALL YOGA! 

BEGINNING LABOR DAY WEEKEND...

As the summer draws to an end (sadly for some for us), we look forward to a process of  reaping the harvest and letting go.  Fall is a time of transition and it is evident everywhere around us.  After the glorious celebration of summer, the trees and shrubs are undressing in preparation for the winter, the air is crisping up, and the wind is blowing whispering coming of the winter tides.  Although this may leave us feeling slightly down, empty, and/or anxious, the possibility to strip down to a quiet essence of being and and savor the simplicity is an opportunity for introspection.  Come slow and quiet down with us in a practice to balance the Vata dosha and learn how you can best take care of yourself this season....  

Since March 2013, this donation based Meet Up group has aimed to provide a light-hearted and non-competitive space.  One can expect clear instructions, demonstration, expert hands-on assistance, and achieve greater flexibility, strength, balance, focus, and sense of ease with regular attendance.  

Extra mats and blocks are limited, kindly bring yours if you have them.


*To offset Meetup Organizer's fees, a suggested donation between $7-10 will be greatly appreciated*

Thank you and please do post any questions.  I hope to see you soon! 

Jennifer ( 500 Hour Yoga Alliance Registered  Teacher)

results.description:
LEADER: Louise Parnell ([masked] or[masked] (c)[masked])

RATING: B 5 B

Meet at 10 AM at the Old Ball Field on Tiorati Brook Rd.  We will follow the Red Cross Trail to the Hasenclever Mine, which was founded in 1765 and was once considered the most valuable iron ore mine in America.  We will then walk to the cemetery by Rock House Mt.  TC Map 119.


*   *   *   *   *   *

Our full hike schedule can be viewed on our website at hudsonhikers.org, and some hikes are also posted on our Facebook page.

After attending two hikes/events, please consider joining the North Jersey Ramapo Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club to support our outdoor recreation and conservation activities.  Membership comes with a variety of benefits including a 10% discount at Ramsey Outdoor; our annual holiday party and social; special events such as our traditional day-outing to the Mohonk Mountain House; a subscription to ADK’s bi-monthly magazine, Adirondac; and the opportunity to contribute to the preservation and extension of hiking lands and viewsheds in our region.

New hikers are strongly encouraged to select hikes appropriate to their capabilities. North Jersey Ramapo Chapter hikes are rated for pace (A, B or C), mileage, and terrain (A, B or C), with "C" designating easier hikes and "A" more challenging ones. We recommend that new hikers should first try a "C" or short "B" hike before undertaking a more difficult one; otherwise, you may not fully enjoy the hiking experience. If you have any doubts, please contact the hike leader in advance. 

Pace Ratings: 
     A = Fast - 2.5 mph or faster 
     B = Moderate - about 2 mph 
     C = Easy - 1.5 mph or less 

Distance:Noted in miles 

Terrain Ratings:
     A = Strenuous, long/steep climbs and descents, 
             possible rock scrambling
     B = Moderate climbs and descents
     C = Generally flat with little elevation change 

For example, a hike rated “B 7 A” is a moderately paced hike of approximately 7 miles with steep climbs and/or descents and possible rock scrambling. 

If you join us for a hike, please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness, including ensuring that the hike is appropriate for your level of fitness, that you wear the proper clothing, and bring the proper gear, food and water (see the ADK's recommended Hiking Essentials and guidelines, below).

Leaders have the right, responsibility and sole discretion to refuse any hiker he/she deems to be not properly attired, prepared, or otherwise fit to safely complete the hike. 

HIKERS' GUIDELINES:

  Risks:  As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

  Footwear and Clothing:  Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes.  Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

  Drink and Food:  Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

  Other responsibilities:  Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them.  Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian.  No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21.  The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike.  Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

  Maps:  The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

  Abbreviations:  NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

  Expense Sharing:  When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

  Dog-Friendly Hikes:  Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly."  If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.

NO SHOW/LATE CANCELLATION POLICY:
Please be considerate of event hosts/organizers and others who may want to attend an event by not being a "NO SHOW" (failing to show up when you've RSVP'd "yes") or a "LATE CANCEL" (changing RSVP to a "no" within 24 hours of an event).  If you have a history of No Shows and/or Late Cancels, we may have to bump you to the waiting list for meetups with limited space, in favor of those with a positive attendance history.

results.description:
A healthy mind and body is key to a successful, joyful and happy life. Learning to manage the mind, emotions, stress in today's world is a much needed life skill. Did you know our very own breath actually holds a secret to a healthy and happy existence? :) Each one of us possesses the ability to calm the mind and recharge the body within minutes! In this one hour workshop we will explore the connection between the breath, mind and body and learn a few breathing techniques to relax and rejuvenate. We will top it off with a guided meditation - no experience necessary :)

The workshop is also an introduction to the Art of Living Happiness Program that has benefited over 40 million people worldwide . Don't hesitate to ask for the upcoming program.

So come join us!

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play anywhere in NYC, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
Please read carefully: This event is being sponsored by Dave Cervini's newyorksocialnetwork.com and several of their partner Meet Up groups.  The number of people registered on this Meet Up represent only a portion of those actually attending. If you have any questions or want to know how many are attending please contact the event host at [masked]. .

We now have a block of 40 tickets  to see the J-E-T-S vs The PHILADELPHIA EAGLES at Met Life Stadium for the 1pm kickoff that includes a traditional all inclusive tailgate party before the game, PLUS a chance to go onto the field at Halftime for the halftime show!  No other group has an offer like this!  If you are a fan or not, seeing a live NFL football game in person is an awesome experience! 

Our tailgate party in the parking lot begins at 10am! If you have never tailgated before, it is one of the most unique people watching and social experiences you will ever have.  We'll have burgers, dogs, chicken wings, sausage and Peppers chips, soda, beer, wine and all the fixings you need to get ready for the game.  We will make a vegetarian selection for those who would like.


You can get to the stadium yourself or meet the group near Penn Station and head out together via NJ Transit.  Game is on rain or shine.  No refunds within 14 days.

Can I come alone? Yes 97% of those attending will be coming on their own.

Do I need to know about football? No, it is easily explained by one of our group if you do not know the game.  The best part about the experience is the people watching and the passion of the die hard fans.

Where are the Seats: The seats will be in the upper section of the stadium in the end zone 322 stacked 10 and 10 so that you can talk to others in the group.

What to expect:  A mix of fans and non fans both men and women.

What to wear: Be comfortable and casual.

**************************************************

$120 Includes: admission to game, all inclusive tailgate party with food & drinks, special on field opportunity for half time show.

Special Instructions:

There will be a group leaving the city  meeting at Starbucks on 7th ave and 31st street in the city for those who wish to travel out together at 8:50am.

You may also drive to stadium yourself.

Tailgate is on Orange lot across from IZOD Center

iF There does not seem to be a lot of people registered on this Meet Up,are  there more people going?   Yes as explained, this event is being promoted by several Meet Up groups and www.newyorksocialnetwork.com

There will 40 people attending.  If you have any questions you can contact the event organizer directly at [masked] or call[masked]

results.description: service at North Church Queens starts at 10 am and goes till 11 am. then there is fellowship which i like to call snacks and a low key party. the gardens are beautiful to visit. the bible is read by someone in the congregation. passages are the same for many of the churches regardless of the denomination- some set calendar thing that many Christian Churches go by. we sing some songs which is fun cause our organist really rocks! then there is the sermon which are most often, very interesting. we say some prayers, get forgiven for our sins~ as we forgive others who sin against us. communion is every first sunday. it is bread and grape juice in those individual small plastic shot glass type things.
results.name: Go to Church!

group.name: Spirituality, Exercise & Peace @ North Church Queens

results.description:
Come join Brooklyn Boys on Bikes for a day of picking apples at a local New York-state orchard. This is an annual tradition and one of our most popular rides.

This year we'll be visiting the Outhouse Orchards in North Salem, NY. They are famous for their mouthwatering selection of homemade doughnuts, fudge, pies and of course apples :) You'll be able to pick your own apples and sample everything else the farm has to offer: delicious treats, apple cider doughnuts and much more.

Meet us at Grand Central Station at 10:30AM by the main information booth at the center of the concourse. We'll be taking Metro North up to Purdys (departing at 10:51AM). The plan is to cycle around the Titicus Reservoir on our way to the orchard and check out the scenic Putnam Trailway on our way back. We should be returning to the city around 6:30PM.


Things to bring: plenty of water, light snacks (for the train ride), flat tire repair kit (if you have one), cash for lunch and apples.
results.name: Apple Picking Ride

results.description:
Eileen McCarren, Tournament Director


Eligible:   All members and guests with at least some experience.  PLEASE PLAY!  More players equal more fun. No first-time players.

Cost:  Free.

Registration: Each player must register on Meetup by midnight 9/26. This will help Eileen and the committee set up teams in advance.  

10:30 AM Set-up, check-in, and team formation.  

11:00 AM Games begin. Anyone not at pier 66 by 10:30 am may be disqualified, as it is very difficult to juggle team makeup and keep them balanced.  PLEASE do not be late.

Team Formation  The Tournament Director and Tournament Committee will make up teams, probably each captained by an A or B player, and aim for roughly equal strength teams with each team having a variety of skills.  We’ll play five-person teams if 20 or more people register; 4-person teams if fewer.

Maximum 1 goal per half per player  Unless all players on team have scored in half

Goalie Limit  A-team quality goalies cannot be primary goalies (may defend against fast breaks only).  Tournament director to categorize.

Goal Multiplier – for all rounds  Each player suggests their own category - but Tournament Director has final determination.

  A & B team levels: each goals = 1 point

  C Team level: each goal = 2 points

Tackling  Each player may announce if they wish to be capsized.  Players who do not wish to be capsized may not capsize others.

ROUND-ROBIN

3 points for win; 1 point draw; 0 points loss

Playoff seeding: Points; Goal differential (max. 4/game); goals

PLAYOFFS - Handicapping


4 plays 1; 2 plays 3

Consolation and championship games playoff handicaps: Teams get ranking differential (4th minus 1st means 4th place team starts with 3 points; 3rd place team starts with 1 point against 2)

Tournament Director is sole arbiter of rules, and may interpret or make up additional rules, for fun or fairness, as she sees fit.

Prizes for Round-Robin & Playoff Champions
results.name: New York Kayak Polo September Mash-UP

results.name: Park Challenge Boot Camp

results.description:
Margaret Matsumoto    "Making Peace with your Body: Flow-motion of Tai Chi"       

 Margaret will talk about strengthening the Mind-Body-Spirit connection through conscious movement.  Through presentation and a very brief segment of experiential work  "on our feet"  (standing by your chair), she will encourage us to connect deeply within, to foster a process of healing and compassion, and to reinforce our ethos of service to the common good.   

 Margaret is in her 40th year of teaching Tai Chi and Qi-gong. She specializes in training and certifying others to teach for the NY School of Tai Chi Chuan and its national coordinating organization, the Tai Chi Foundation. She has enjoyed teaching our Saturday morning Tai Chi class at Ethical for the past 4 years and encourages any ECSW members or friends to visit just to watch or to join us in class.
results.name: Making Peace with your Body: Flow-motion of Tai Chi

results.how_to_find_us: Just look for us

results.description:
One more outdoor class! Class will be taught by Kelly.

Beginner-friendly yoga on Sundays in Central Park! Suggested donation of $5-$10 to help recruit instructors and fund advertising, but payment is not required to attend! Please contact the organizer if you are interested in donating via PayPal or Square Payments.

Meet at 100th Street and Central Park West by the bench near the entrance to the park at 10:45am.  Bring a mat, water, and friends!  We'll head up together to the Great Hill where class will take place. If you are familiar with the Great Hill you can meet us there closer to 11:00am.

Please RSVP here even if you *may* be coming so teachers can get in touch in the case of weather-related cancelations!

See you on the Great Hill!
results.name: Donation-based (optional) yoga in Central Park on Sundays

Through song and sharing of her experiences teaching philosophy to young children, she will lead a session to share hopes for the initiative.  The program is designed for all ages and we especially invite those families who are eager to provide a dignity-based learning experience for their children.

For More about Amy Blake, visit the Ethical Culture Schedule Page at http://www.essexethical.org/schedule.html#amy.

Terri, Irene, Celeste & Sarah ❤️

S'mores, campfire songs, hotdogs - and NO bugs or snakes!! What could be better than camping on the rooftop of a Manhattan Building with a Hudson River View!!
Dogs will play Musical Sit to campfire songs, relax in our various Tents, while their parents enjoy campfire goodies and meeting new friends. We will also have a contest ($10 contest fee) for the dog who is wearing the Best Camping Outfit! Title of "Miss or Mr. Campfire"! Come join us!! (Event tickets are $25 on Eventbrite or $30 in person.)   Partial proceeds of this event will be contributed to the Mayor's Alliance for Animal Care and Control on stage at the New York Pet Fashion Show in February 2016.
results.name: Come Indoor Camping with the PupScouts!!

results.description:
Once again I have realized we've read several novels in a row by men. It's time for some ladies. And as we just finished one version of a murder novel, let's try another in a different flavor. 

Many members have mentioned Donna Tartt's Pulitzer Prize winning novel The Goldfinch as something they'd like to read. However,The Goldfinch is a hefty 740 pages. Of Tartt's three published novels, her first, The Secret History, is the shortest, weighing in at a mere 570. It is also one of her most controversial, with critics sharply divided in their reviews. Tartt began The Secret History when she was still at college and was bought by $450,000 by Knopf after a bidding war. A 75,000 print order was made for the first edition (as opposed to the usual 10,000 order for a debut novel), and the book became a bestseller. 

Set in New England, The Secret History tells the story of a closely knit group of six classics students at a small, elite Vermont college, Hampden College, similar in many respects to Bennington College (in Bennington, Vermont) where Tartt was a student from 1982 to 1986.

Under the influence of their charismatic classics professor, a group of clever, eccentric misfits at an elite New England college discover a way of thinking and living that is a world away from the humdrum existence of their contemporaries. But when they go beyond the boundaries of normal morality their lives are changed profoundly and forever, and they discover how hard it can be to truly live and how easy it is to kill. The Secret History is a study of ruin, of lives blighted forever by adolescent hubris.


The story is an inverted detective story, not a Whodunit but a Whydunit. The novel is a page-turner, but there is more to The Secret History than plot alone. The novel is written in a florid, Neo-Romanticist prose style, in keeping with its romanticist themes of aesthetic beauty and its tendency to draw connections to Edwardian and Victorian literary references as well as classical civilizations. It has been referred to as "quality trash for highbrows." That sounds absolutely delightful to me.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll meet in the northwest corner of the Sheep Meadow, by 67th Street and West Drive, near the big tree halfway between Mineral Springs and Tavern on the Green. For the location check out the map--I've moved the red pointer the spot!
results.name: Donna Tartt's The Secret History

group.name: NYC Prize-Winning Book Club & Vegan Potluck

results.description:
Hi all,

That's right- we'll be chewing on both poetry and artisan NY cuisine. We'll be meeting at 11:00 A.M. this coming Sunday at Smorgasburg in Williamsburg to hang out for a bit. We'll then retire to The Brooklyn Bridge Park for our weekly 1:00 meeting to share poetry and learn some eye-training exercises. Hope to see everyone there, and don't worry if you missed our first meeting! All those who can't make Smorgasbord are welcome to come at 1:00, and vice-versa.
results.name: Poetry munch

LOCATION: UN HQ, CR 3, New York

Space is limited. You must RSVP to [masked]


(Please indicate if you do NOT have the UN badge)

CONCEPT NOTE, DEVELOPMENT IN THE DIGITAL AGE

A High-Level panel discussion co-hosted by Estonia, the USA and the World Bank Group...

Over the last two decades, digital technologies have had a profound impact on social and economic development.

No other major technology has reached so many people in such a short time. Today, more people in developing countries have access to a mobile phone than to electricity or clean water. The various benefits of the digital revolution are undeniable—easier communication, greater access to information, and new forms of leisure, to name a few. In the developing world the focus is gradually shifting to generating the broader benefits typically associated with technology—higher economic growth, more jobs and better public services.

A discussion on how to make digital technologies a more effective force for development is timely, in light of the UN Summit on Post-2015 Development Agenda and after the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG). It is also useful to consider whether and how digital technologies can accelerate the process of attaining these goals. The forthcoming World Development Report 2016: Digital Dividends, to be launched in January 2016, provides many useful facts and analysis to anchor this discussion.

In this context, the Government of the Republic of Estonia, the Government of the United States, and the World Bank will co-host a High-Level Side Event, Development in the Digital Age, on September 27, 2015.

The discussion will focus on two policy areas that improve the impact of digital technologies on development. First, to promote policy and regulatory environments that will make the Internet more accessible, affordable, open and safe. Second, how to make digital technologies a more effective force for development and whether and how digital technologies can accelerate the process of attaining these goals.

Ninety percent of people without access to the Internet live in the developing world. Bridging the digital divide between and within countries—across borders, gender, income and age—is essential in the emerging digital economy. Along with better connectivity, the Digital Revolution has opened up new possibilities for disadvantaged and excluded groups. However, these technologies have also brought  new set of challenges, such as cybersecurity,  maintaining an open Internet, and protecting users’ privacy. The panel discussion will address various private sector initiatives as well as government actions. For example the U.S. State Department’s soon to be launched new diplomatic initiative, to help catalyse public-private partnerships to close the global digital divide. It will also explore the policy priorities for the global community to create an open and trusted environment in the digital world.

Over the last decade, digital technologies have been a source of significant economic growth and net job creation, as well as an important force for transparency and accountability around the world. Although significant progress has been made with respect to expanding access and in turn benefits, additional efforts on the part of all stakeholders are needed to connect the unconnected. The panel discussion will explore the policy options to amplify the development impact of digital technologies. In doing so, it will survey the experience of countries with strong track records on digital development such as Estonia, or aspiring such as Rwanda or Tanzania and draw policy lessons for other.


The format will be a panel discussion. Following the introduction by the Moderator, each Speaker will make an introductory statement followed by a moderated discussion, in which the Speakers would also answer the questions
results.name: Development in the Digital Age

results.description:
I will be happy to share with you a very scenic route that I consider to be one of the most romantic places I have seen so far in NYC :
The Untermyer Gardens is an historic park in Yonkers (http://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/20/arts/untermyer-gardens-in-yonkers-is-being-tended-once-again.html?_r=1), located above the Hudson River.

Have a look on Google images at « untermyer gardens » : We will see the Temple of Love, which is the centerpiece of the beautiful rock garden; and the 'Vista Overlook' that was modeled on a similar series of long descending stairs at the famous Villa D'Este with romans columns imported from Italy !

It's a great, sociable walk that will inspire our conversation in French ! Below the Gardens is the Old Croton Aqueduct path (National Historic Landmark status). We will end with a walk on the Old Croton Aqueduct (an easy, leveled dirt path) after the lunch.


NOTICE THAT :

-There is no place to buy lunch along the way. Bring lunch, sun protection (maybe?), water, and comfortable walking shoes.
-There is no admission fee to the Untermyer Gardens.
-This walk is about 4 1/2 miles and moderate paced. You don't have to walk on the Old Croton Aqueduc after to see the Gardens, you can leave from Greystone station if you want after visiting the Gardens, or Yonkers, etc..The Old Croton Aqueduc is all its way close to the railway.
-The meeting time is (before lunch) at 11:00 PM. IF THE METRO-NORTH TRAIN IS LATE, I WILL WAIT FOR THE LATE-ARRIVING TRAIN:)
DIRECTIONS ?
Public Transportation by Metro-North:  Take the No. 1 subway train to Marble Hill/225th Street, which is one block from the Metro-North's Marble Hill station. Then take the Metro-North train from Marble Hill to Greystone. Try to buy a ticket at the Marble Hill station's vending machine before boarding the train (Purchasing a regular fare ticket on board the train is considerably more expensive).You can also take this Metro-North train from several other stations, including Grand Central Terminal and 125th Street in Harlem. If you take the train from Grand Central Terminal, the fare will be higher than taking the train from Marble Hill. The fare depends on the zone.
Below is a schedule of Metro-North's Hudson Line on the weekend.
http://web.mta.info/mnr/html/planning/schedules/pdf/HUD_SS_apr262015.pdf
-IMPORTANT : Before the walk, there are no restrooms available at the Metro-North Greystone Station (no stores or shops near this station). There are restrooms available on the Metro-North train. Later on, restrooms will be available in the Untermyer Gardens.
-If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, just please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". There is no need to post why you can't make the event. Merci !

In case my phone number is[masked]/[masked]

A bientôt !Alex

results.description:
Paddle amid the scenery of Cornwall Bay, Storm King Mountain and the Hudson Highlands for an up-close view of the ruins of Bannerman's Island. Bannerman's Castle is located on Bannerman's Island (a/k/a Pollopel Island) in the Hudson River, a few miles south of the Beacon-Newburgh Bridge. The castle was built as a weapons arsenal by Francis Bannerman VI, a businessman who dealt in military surplus from the Spanish-American war.


Maybe you have seen it, paddled around it, wondered about it or have been one of the few who have been on Bannermans Island. A scenic ruin, this 6.5 acre island is filled with legend. The castle is a property of the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation. A non-profit organization, The Bannerman Castle Trust, was formed over a decade ago to rehabilitate the island and eventually, open it to the public.  As the access to the island is controlled by the trust, the kayak tour will follow around the island, and not land on it.

A preview of the trip can be read here: https://mikekelseyadventures.wordpress.com/2013/04/10/paddling-through-time-destination-kayaking-to-the-hudsons-bannermans-island/


Please note this trip is not for first timers need to be good with kayaks. As with all kayaking trips there is a risk that your boat could capsize and you could get wet. All participants should know how to swim and be comfortable on the water. Be prepared with a set of dry clothes in the car just in case.

All Kayaks need to be 12 feet or longer and sit-in only,  If you want to go and need a kayak please go to http://www.awayadventureguide.com/ or call[masked]

Go on 9W, past West Point, past the town of Cornwall-on-Hudson, and then across Moodna Creek, which is pretty well marked with a sign on your right as you cross the bridge.

Plum Point Lane is the first right after the creek, around 0.3 miles, between a bowling alley and a Toyota dealer.

The sign, which is a bit hidden by the bowling alley sign, says "Kowawese Unique Area," not Plum Point Lane. (The Hagstrom map calls it Plum Point Lane)Turn right and into the unique area, which is actually a state park.

The put-in is at a beach just past the parking lot.
results.name: Let's Kayak Bannerman's Castle

results.description:
Topic: Lying

Speaker: Emily Newman

Details: Is lying ethical? We are surrounded by falsehoods, exaggerations, denial, and sarcasm; that affect our judgment and shape our actions for better and worse. We must first learn what is a lie, how are they used and viewed in society, and why do we lie. Together we will explore lying and try to find the truest, most honest answer.

About the Speaker: Emily Newman is the Communications Coordinator of the American Ethical Union and co-chair of the their Communications Committee. She is a member of the Future of Ethical Societies (FES), Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, New York Society for Ethical Culture, and Secretary of the National Ethical Service at the United Nations. After receiving her MA in Professional Writing from Carnegie Mellon University, Emily worked on publicity for non-profits and small businesses, as well as editing for the United Nations.


Sunday programs are held at 11:00 AM at the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture. For more information, please visit our website: <a>http://www.rysec.org </a>;

Our wide ranging curriculum allows kids to examine themselves, their community and the world in general. We teach about different cultures, philosophies and religions. We encourage our students to ask questions, think for themselves and make up their own minds about the bigger questions in life. Our children develop strong values and ethical standpoints. results.description:
My favorite adult ed speaker!!!


 Professor Gary Dorrien, whom Cornell West has called “the preeminent social ethicist in North America today,” is the author of The New Abolition: W.E.B. Du Bois and the Black Social Gospel - newly released this month by Yale University Press. Drawing upon the resources of this treatise he will address issues presented by American theologians Reverdy Ransom and Reinhold Niebuhr on the quest for racial and social justice in America.

Sept 20: Defying White Supremacy: Reverdy Ransom and the Black Social Gospel
Sept 27: The Niebuhr Problem: Reinhold Niebuhr and the Social Gospel in Black & White

Gary Dorrien, Ph.D is the Reinhold Niebuhr Professor of Theology and Social Ethics at Union Theological Seminary in New York City, Professor of Religion at Columbia University, and a Visiting Lecturer at the Harvard Divinity School. The author of 17 books and some 275 articles ranging across the fields of ethics, social theory, theology, philosophy, politics, economics and history, he has a long history of active participation in social justice organizations. His book Economy, Difference, Empire: Social Ethics for Social Justice (2010) is based on his lectures on economic democracy, racial and gender justice, and anti-imperial politics. More recently Professor Dorrien published a critique of the Obama presidency, The Obama Question: A Progressive Perspective (2012), and lectured widely on it. More than 40 reviewers have described his trilogy, The Making of American Liberal Theology [masked]) as the definitive work on the history of liberal theological thought from the colonial era to the present.
results.how_to_find_us: I will be in standing in back of room....I look a lot like my photo!
results.name: Black Theology and Social Justice in America:Gary Dorrien, Ph.D

From the Broadway Cares website:
Be a part of the biggest day for Broadway fans as the 29th Annual Broadway Flea Market & Grand Auction returns this fall to Times Square, Shubert Alley and West 44th Street.

Find one-of-a-kind showbiz treasures, meet your favorite cast members and bid on exclusive backstage experiences.

The free-to-the-public, once-a-year outdoor market will stretch from the pedestrian plaza along Broadway between 43rd and 44th Streets, and down West 44th Street to Eighth Avenue, while filling the Flea Market’s first home in Shubert Alley. The always popular Autograph Table and Photo Booth will again take over the deck of Junior's Restaurant in Shubert Alley at West 45th Street.

Search for that missing piece of your Broadway collection, including out-of-print cast recordings and lost Playbills from almost any show you can imagine. Get lost in the stacks of signed memorabilia, costume sketches, props and photographs. There are treasures to be found in every price range.

More than 60 tables full of Broadway memorabilia, collectible Playbills and one-of-a-kind gems will line West 44th Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. Among the shows scheduled to have tables this year are Aladdin, Allegiance, Avenue Q, Beautiful – The Carole King Musical, The Book of Mormon, Hamilton, Kinky Boots, The Lion King, Matilda The Musical, The Phantom of the Opera, Something Rotten! and Wicked, with more to be announced.

The always popular Autograph Table and Photo Booth will welcome more than 60 actors from Broadway’s best shows.

(The flea market is actually open from 10am - 7pm if you want to arrive a little early!)

results.description:
Are you looking to BALANCE your training & stretching?

Are you looking for RELIEF from joint wear, tightness, pain, and/or discomfort?

Looking for a complementary training to ENHANCE your overall well being on and off the track?

Would you like to RELEASE physical, mental and emotional tensions?

About Yin Yang Yoga...A typical Yoga class is ‘Yang’ in style and focuses on active heating and muscular contraction - by combining it with ‘Yin’, a more passive, nourishing, and cooling practice, this uniquely designed class WILL balance your whole being in training!

Why For Runners/Athletes? - Lengthening and releasing effect from repetitive movements (overuse) on sheets of connective tissue (fascia) can overtime shorten and tighten in ingrained patterns around muscles. This can make one more prone to having injuries, abnormal posture, and inefficiency, as well as asymmetrical weakening. By targeting selected and rotated key areas in weekly Yin Yang Yoga class, one can better release tension, move with ease, and benefit from improved posture and injury prevention.

The Yin Yang Yoga for Runners class begins with series of held Yin floor postures to open the meridian channels/chakras, or the subtle pathways of the body. While surrendering into the edge of each pose for 2-5 minutes, students are guided in the cultivation of observance and breath, as they experience release of connective tissues and the stagnant energy around the hips, thighs, and lower back. Awareness is guided to sensations in the body that can be grounding and powerful experience of the NOW. The Yang or moving practice allows students to integrate the newly released energy, joint spaces for circulation, and flexibility, into active strengthening postures and movement sequences. Freedom of breath, alignment, and mental clarity will be elicited deeply during, after the class, and into one's training.

After our INTRO CLASS ON 9/10: "Jennifer is an awesome instructor. Her sessions are informative and her teaching style is patient, clear and inspires me to attain increased fitness. I look forward to attending her class. The very next day I was able to push through my usual 3-4 miles to complete a 6 mile run." Sandra

AND another student reported achieving best time running a 18 mile course...


**10 Classes Only - Join weekly for maximum benefits and donate suggested $15 per class for this this performance enhancing class not offered anywhere else in NYC!


PLEASE RSVP "YES" only if you will make it to class (or update) and bring a mat if you have one.

See you and/or would you please pass this limited opportunity on? Thank you!

Namaste, Jennifer, RYT-500hr

results.description:
Let’s tour what is still the quirkiest neighborhood in NYC, Manhattan’s East Village. We’ll view or visit an oddball antiques store, a local opera house, a sidewalk with old movie-star footprints, a witchcraft store, a secluded old cemetery open only one Sunday a month, the Hell’s Angel’s headquarters (we won’t go in!), a chocolate-egg-cream emporium, the city’s first public library, the city’s most colorful church, an art gallery or two, a restaurant with lovely stained glass windows, provocative street murals or mosaics, beautiful, historic buildings, creative community gardens—and a slew of other oddities that enliven this vibrant neighborhood.

PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING DETAILS SO YOU'RE PROPERLY PREPARED. AND PLEASE DO NOT RSVP "NO" UNLESS YOU'RE CHANGING FROM A PREVIOUS "YES."

PACE: Moderate (2 to 2.5 mph) NOT SLOW. PLEASE, If you want to go slowly, this is not the walk for you.

DISTANCE: About 3-4 miles. We'll finish at around 5 PM, but you can leave earlier, of course.

LUNCH: Bring your own. We'll start eating around 1:30 PM.

COST: $2, in part to cover Meetup's organizer fee, plus a small, voluntary contribution at the Marble Cemetery.

TRANSPORTATION: L, N, Q, R, 4, 5, and 6 trains all stop at Union Square. F, B, D, and M stop at 14th St. and 6th Ave., a 5-minute brisk walk to Union Square. For more details, consult hopstop.com, mta.tripplanner.org, or both, since each is occasionally inaccurate.

WAITING LIST: Sign up and be patient, no matter how many are waiting--there will be many cancellations, especially shortly before the walk. And if you're in the top 20 on the list (shown below the main list on the right side of this page on a computer--not an app or mobile) at any time before the walk starts you can come. As a courtesy to others waiting for a spot, please do not sign up unless you intend to go, rather than just as a placeholder in case nothing better turns up.

IF YOU CAN'T COME: No need to let me know. But please change your RSVP online if you previously said yes.
results.how_to_find_us: The statue is at the rear of the big open space at the south end of the park. I'll be wearing a red cap, in front of the statue.
results.name: Tour the East Village
Bedazzle our resumes or halloween costumes for our kids. Cocktails & convos.

results.description:
This is a weekly introductory improv class taught Sundays from 12pm-3pm.

-- Are you a bit shy and looking to get more comfortable with your public speaking? 

-- Are you a working professional hoping to be a bit more spontaneous during your meetings and interactions with co-workers? 

-- Or are you an actor or improv comedian looking to take your craft to the next level or get more reps?

Then this is the class for you! In this class, you will learn the fundamentals of scene work (role playing). You'll be on your feet quite a bit as I'm believer that you learn (and have more fun) through doing rather than hearing an instructor talk. Brief individual notes will be given, if that's what you're looking for, and tailored to your level of experience. At the end of each class, I'm confident you'll feel a sense of accomplishment that will leave you more energized and excited to tackle the challenges of everyday life, whether at your work place or in your personal life. 

This class is $10.  If money is an issue for you, let me know and we can work something out.  The cost goes to pay for the cost of the room rental, Meetup fees, and website.  

Hope to see you there!


Steve

www.improvnow.com

www.facebook.com/improvnow

Steve Ling is an alumnus of the improv programs of the Upright Citizens Brigade, Peoples Improv Theater, Magnet Theater, & Annoyance Theater. He regularly produces and performs improv, musical improv, & hip hop improv across NYC.

results.description:
If it rains, we will meet at our usual indoor spot. Bread & Butter on Park Ave at 29th St, upstairs.

A small, supportive group for artists of all types to come together and talk about and share their creative projects in a fun, non-judgmental environment. New members welcome. (Each person pays $1 cash at the meetings, just to help offset the costs of having the group hosted here on MeetUp.com.)

Every week, we meet from 12:00 pm to 2:00 pm. Usually, we work through Julia Cameron's creativity building techniques (for example those in The Artist's Way and The Prosperous Heart). We start each session discussing the current week's activity (morning pages, artist's dates, synchronicities, creative endeavors, etc) and then participate in an agreed upon exercise/task (bring paper and pen please).


Normally, on the third Sunday of the month, we share our artistic projects in a kind of "Show & Tell" so that we can get to know each other's work and support it. Not mandatory - only for those who wish to share or present their work.


This is a very creative and supportive small group. Please join us.

results.description:
Hello all,

Atlantic Antic is an annual mega street fair that will take place on Sunday, September 27, 2015, rain or shine. (See: http://atlanticave.org/ )

The Brooklyn LP and the Manhattan LP will again have a booth there. And we will again conduct an Operation Politically Homeless (OPH). With our OPH, we will be able to identify libertarians and bring them into our folds. If you have been to past Atlantic Antics, you know that it's a tremendous street fair that's attended by literally millions of people. You also know about the huge foot traffic that goes by our booth.

We need you to help us at the booth! Can we count on you?

Our booth will be on the South Side of Atlantic Avenue (you'll be out of direct sun), between Henry and Hicks Streets, closer to Henry. Its "Space Number" is AS32, which will be near 108 Atlantic Avenue. The closest subway station is Borough Hall, of the 2,3, 4, and R lines. FWIW, our booth's GPS coordinates are:

Latitude and Longitude (Decimal)
Latitude:[masked]
Longitude: [masked]


Latitude and Longitude (ddd.mm.ss)
Latitude: N 40° 41′ 26.4″
Longitude: W 73° 59′ 47.68″

Atlantic Antic officially starts at 12:00 PM and ends at 6:00 PM, though we will start closing around 5:30 PM. If you can come help us set up at around 10:15 AM, that would be swell. You don't have to stay for the entire fair. Stay as long or as short as you like. But whichever, you will have a blast. I guarantee it.

Questions, comments?

Be there or be rhomboid!

Thanks for reading.

Alton

results.description:
Photographer & Model Photoshoot Society Presents:

"Pre-Halloween Glamour Shoot #2 w/Neesy & Nani - Sept. 27th"


We're back this month with the second of our pre-halloween glamour shoots. We are thrilled to have members favorite Neesy Rizzo back and returning favorite, Nani Wells. This is sure to be an amazing shoot with these two.

About the Shoot: 

We continue with our pre-halloween glamour shoots this month. The ladies will be dressed in sexy "costumes" with a lingerie/glamour styling. With some luck with the weather, we will be able to shoot outdoors. Indoors, we'll continue with the pinup setups and glamour lighting.

For new members: Please take the time to read the info below about how the Meetup is organized and how the shooting parameters are setup.

Cost: $80

(Cash preferred, Credit Cards/Paypal ok with $5 added for surcharge)

(Non-Commercial Release provided onsite or PDF version to email registered upon check-in.)

Models:

Neesy Rizzo: Instagram and Facebook

(PhotoCredits: NandoPro)

(Photo Credits: Photodepotbyjoe)

Nani Wells: Instagram

(Photo Credits: NandoPro) 

(Photo Credits: Photodepotbyjoe)

One-on-Ones: The models will be available for half hour one on one shoots after the Meetup. If you want to pre-book time before the shoot, send me a message.

NEW Shared One-on-Ones: We are also implementing a system that has been working for the past few Meetups. It's the sharing of a half hour one on one with a fellow photographer. It can be shared together for the whole half hour or 15 minutes each photographer. 

_______________________________________________________________________

About the Studio:

The studios is a beautiful 3,000 sq. ft., climate controlled,  fully functional studio. (Professional in-house lights, props, various seamless backdrops, actual commercial photography sets, kitchen, waiting room, meeting/presentation room, the works!) It's conveniently located to major highways and a 20-30 minute public transportation ride to and from NY.

About The Meetup Format:

We will keep the group small although we have the space to accommodate a big group. This keeps things from feeling rushed and overwhelming. Each photographer will have a set amount of time per look. This will allow you to  shoot as you would in an actual client shoot and not have to worry about the number of shots you are taking. (This proved to be ideal in our previous shoots as far as being able to get "the shot" and enough time to do so. Think of it as a mini one-on-one time with the model.) During the shoot we may opt to give a theme a direction to shoot for. As it would be for an actual client. (Ex: If the setup calls for a "cover shot" then it will give you a direction to aim for and to consider what equipment to use or what mood to capture.) No worries, bring what lens or lenses you have, you'll learn to use what you have for best results. We strive to bring forth real world conditions and parameters so there is a methodology to a setup or theme.

Check-in Procedure and Disclaimers:

Check-in - When you arrive, there will be a quick check-in. This will mostly be so you can read and adhere to the studio/group shoot guidelines and make payment for the shoot before we start. This will also let us send you the release forms in PDF format if we don't have physical copies available.

Releases - We will have one non-commercial release signed by the model through the studio only. (No additional releases will be signed.) If you need a commercial release signed, you can make arrangements with the model directly. Additional compensation for this is between the model and photographer.

Right to Refuse - We have the right to refuse a member's RSVP to the Meetup. It's a small community and models keep detailed info on photographers also. If we feel there is justifiable reason to refuse a RSVP, we will exercise that right.

Signups - Please signup when you know you will attend. If the signup passes the point to book another model and then we get no shows it's not fair to your fellow photographers who would be on a waiting list. It also puts the organizers in a tough spot, financially after booking an additional model to compensate for a bigger group. So, at the very least give us 3 days notice that you will not be able to attend or in case of no show, we will have to remove you from the group. When emergencies come up past the 3 days notice, followup with an email and we can make exceptions on a case by case basis. 

Model Cancellation - If a model cancels or a last minute model change occurs, you will have the option to cancel beforehand or not attend the Meetup on the day of, if it happens upon arrival to the Meetup.

Waitlist - When you are on a wait list, please be mindful as this is also considered a RSVP of availability. So, if we add another model or someone cancels within the 3 days before the shoot, your wait list status may upgrade to a "Yes". Please be on the lookout for updates on the Meetup page as Meetup sometimes takes longer to notify of a status change.

Updates - Updates will be made on this page up to the date of the Meetup or the night before. Emails will also be sent but Meetup emails are not always reliable to be sent to a receiver right away. (I've heard of emails arriving 3 hours later if at all.)

Postponements - Weather considerations will be made the night before a shoot or on the day of and the Meetup page will be updated as well as emails sent if a postponement occurs due to inclement weather or some other emergency. Lack of minimum RSVP to hold the event will also cause postponement of the shoot. The night before we would make the call wether to postpone so be on the look out for our email and Meetup page updates.

Any questions please email me at [masked]
results.name: Pre-Halloween Glamour Shoot #2 w/Neesy & Nani - Sept. 27th

results.description:
The 2015 NYC Yarn Crawl will be held Friday, September 25 thru Sunday September 27. Check out the website for more details! 

http://www.yarncrawlnyc.com/stores.htm

Our annual opportunity to visit, en masse,  favorite yarn stores and discover ones that may be new to you.  And, of course, get the advice and encouragement of many of your friends for your purchases.   Most, if not all of the stores have special promotions for this special weekend.  There are also raffles at the individual stores and a scavenger hunt if you manage to visit most of all of them.


Here's our preliminary TIGHT schedule.  I don't like being a nudge, but in order for a group of sociable shoppers to get to all these stores, we will have to keep it moving.

School Products opens at 11:00 am Sunday, if anyone wants to try to duck in there first. The earliest any of the other Manhattan stores opens on Sunday is  12:00 noon. 


Check MTA schedule for weekend service changes.  We will have to take at least one into account Sunday, and i discovered i will have to deal with another one Saturday.


12:00- 12:50  :  Annie and CO - 1763 Second Ave http://www.annieandco.com/                    

12:50 - 1:30 bus to Knitty city


1:30 - 2:20:  Knitty City - 208 W 79 st  http://www.knittycity.com/


2:20-2:21  - walk to Blondies   212 west 79  St/

2:21 - 3:20 Blondies

http://blondiessports.com/   -restaurant/food/refreshment/rest room break.  We should break into groups of no more than 5 or 6 at a table.  Servers move very slowly with large groups.


3:20 - 4:00 travel to seaport yarn


4:00-4:45: Seaport Yarns  - 181 Broadway http://www.seaportyarn.com/


4:45 - 5:10 - travel


5:10 - ???  (store closes at 6:00) Purl Soho - 459 Broome st - http://www.purlsoho.com/purl

leaving Purl Soho, we have several choices: 1. go home to collapse;  2.  find a bar for more beverages and show and tell.  3.   Downtown yarn doesn't close until 7:00..if anyone is up for a mad dash and hasn't been there yet.

After that, options #1 and 2 from above apply.

For those of you who want to visit  more stores,  increase your odds of winning the raffle and/or scavenger hunt (Pints'n'Purls usually manages to have at least one winner), some rough ideas for the other Manhattan stores... and some we are planning to visit just in case...

open late Friday -  Annie's, School Products 13 East 37 St -http://www.schoolproductsyarns.com/, Purl Soho and Downtown Yarns 45 Ave A http://www.downtownyarns.com/

opening early enough Saturday to squeeze in before La Casita - String Yarns - 144 East 74 st http://stringyarns.com/, Seaport and School Products

My personal plan is Downtown Yarns when i get back to Manhattan Friday - and then - hopefully, head out to Brooklyn for Gauge & Tension (thanks Amy and Kristen). I'll try to fit in String on my way to the Lexington Subway , actually to the F train, thanks MTA for weekend service changes....Saturday am.   sorry about that School Products.

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play anywhere in NYC, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>
results.name: Tennis Social

results.description:
Updated September 5th, 2015

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

FALL (Sep - Nov)

As the city cools down we play four times a week. We use Riverside Park with Morningside Park as a backup.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!) 
- Tuesdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!) 
- Thursdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)

Damien 
[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).
results.why: It's fun and you like it...

This is a co-ed adult pick-up game for all levels. 6v6 or 7 v7 depending on attendance. 90 minutes with two 45 minute halves. No slide tackling or rough play. We play with Pugg goals. Pinnies provided.  Shin guards are recommended.


This pick up game is hosted by Coach Moe, Please bring  $4 in cash.

PLEASE UPDATE YOUR RSVP BY MIDNIGHT THE DAY BEFORE THE GAME!

A and C trains to High St.


F train to York St.


N and R trains to Court St.

results.description:
La Flaca serves a distinctly southwestern take on south-of-the-border favorites. The space has an air of sun-baked rusticity, from the tanned-and-tattered walls to the mismatched stump stools lining the entryway. With the exception of a few gringo oddities—shrimp cocktail served in a Clamato-filled martini glass—the menu sticks to middle-priced combinations of Mexican staples. The specialties here range from fried-egg-topped enchiladas to a tomato-heavy puréed-salsa starter.

Although La Flaca operates as a full restaurant, it straddles the line between proper eatery and rowdy saloon, with loudness, late hours, televised sports, and daily happy-hour specials.

Let's come out on a sunday for their popular 2 hrs of unlimited Brunch for only $22

Any brunch dish served with drinks and tea or coffee. Choice of orange juice, frozen margarita, sangria, bloody mary, La Flaca Amber Ale or Mimosa. For Mimosa add $1 per drink. Add $1 for margarita flavor. Add $1 for Sangrita. 

Brunch Menu Below

http://www.laflacanyc.com/brunch-menu/

We already have a table reserved for 10 people, so we will ask for a $5 deposit to reserve your chair. We will be fully refunded once you attend our brunch.
results.name: Brunch at La Flaca

results.description:
Different place this time! Alot of the regulars like this place but we have a lot of new members this year, so I'll explain the Whiskey Rebel.

1) This place has alot of drinks but NO kitchen;just a bar. However, they allow you to bring your own food. They even have menus available to order food to be delivered to the place. 2) If you want to bring something for yourself or to share or nothing at all, that is entirely up to you. You are NOT required to bring anything. 3)We always go all the way to the back of the bar.

4) Don't forget your wallet; there is usually(not always) a bouncer checking ID before you go in. So if you or your guest(s) are under the legal drinking age, I'm sorry. You're going to have to wait till we go back to Nelly Spillanes or another restaurant like that. That's about it.

results.description:
The Fool


Shades of Chekhov. Dima is a Russian plumber in an unnamed town who, during a routine inspection, discovers a giant crack in the façade of a squalid apartment building that warehouses 800 people. Armed with only his integrity and what he considers an ordinary person’s concern for human safety, he alerts his bosses and the municipal authorities – who either don’t believe him or don’t want to because making note of the danger will underscore their previous lack of diligence. Saddled with a brow-beaten father, a cynical shrew of a mother and a fearful wife, Dima presses on for an immediate response to a situation that could turn fatal at any moment.  But will the victim be the residents of the dangerously unstable building – or Dima himself – as he goes up against a corrupt and arrogant power structure? The movie confirms what recent headlines in The New York Times suggest (e.g. “Russian Opposition Activist Is Hospitalized With Mystery Illness”):  that no one with an ounce of decency is safe in Putin’s Russia.

RUSSIA • 2014 • 116 MINS. • IN RUSSIAN WITH ENGLISH SUBTITLES • OLIVE FILMS

http://filmforum.org/film/the-fool-film

--------

Back from a long hiatus.  I hope you can join us this Sunday for our first Russian movie.  Movie time is 1:00 so I will be outside around 12:40 to meet you.  Ideally we can get post-movie drinks at Amity Hall.

See you soon.
results.how_to_find_us: I will be outside the theater, likely in a tweed blazer

results.description:
Prepay @ http://www.weekenddating.com/upcoming.shtml?eventid=5886 required Date & Time: Sunday, September 27, 2015
1 PM:- 5:00 PM

Male ages: all
Female ages: all

Cost: $87.50-$97.50

We will be sitting in the Lodge (rows D and E). Our package for the tickets and pre-mingle is $87.50-$97.50 depending on how early you register.

This event is not meant to be age specific or gender balanced. We will meet for a pre-mingle at a local bar/pub (location announced after you register) and then go to see this AMAZING Broadway show. Price includes the ticket to the show (3:00PM) and the pre-mingle (1 pm).

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sfOdTQ-GIzQ


About the Show

2015 Tony Awards:
Best Revival of a Musical!
Kelli O'Hara, Best Leading Actress in a Musical!
Ruthie Ann Miles, Best Featured Actress in a Musical!
Catherine Zuber, Best Costume Design of a Musical!

Tony winner Bartlett Sher (South Pacific) directs this classic tale of a British schoolteacher's unexpected relationship with the imperious King of Siam.

Featuring a cast of more than 50, choreography based on the original by Jerome Robbins, and a score of treasured songs including "Getting to Know You," "I Whistle a Happy Tune" and "Shall We Dance?" in their glorious, original orchestrations, Lincoln Center Theater's new staging of THE KING AND I invites you to get to know this inspiring and enchanting musical classic.

venue.address_1: West 66th St and Central Park West, New York, NY
venue.name: Central Park - Sheep Meadows

results.description:
What better way to enjoy this great weather than a Saturday afternoon Picnic in Central Park. This is an annual tradition and like Diwali and Holi, we have a Picnic in Central Park every summer. 

I will be getting professional catering done, there will be non alcoholic beverages, munchies including samosas, hummus, nachos and a few more items.

I would have to ask members to pitch in $10 to help me cover the cost of the food.

Alcohol is prohibited by law in Central Park, but as long as people aren't conspicuous or obnoxious, they usually don't get hassled :)

Bring a sheet to lay on, if you can. Games too. Feel free to bring a Frisbee or other fun activity to share/play with others like Frisbee, soccer ball etc

Directions

Enter the park at Central Park West and 67th St. Follow that walkway in, cross West Drive (with all the joggers and bikers heading south). Across that road is the Sheep Meadow.

I shall put a red flag, so look for it and that will be our group :)

See you all soon.
results.name: Funday In Central Park

group.name: "Sikhs in the City" The NY Punjabi and Sikhs Meetup Group

results.description:
The New York Transit Museum is hosting vintage buses in front of their museum for display. Buses from 1910s-1980s. There's plenty of buses to look at. You can even go on board the bus and admire the old seats and old ads. (Seating in the driver seat is off limits.) They will be parked on Boerum Place between State Street and Atlantic Ave. After the buses, you may enter into the museum with $1 admission fee. You can spend all day inside of the museum.

Reminder: Do not eat or drink on the bus!

Also note that the museum is a underground train station, there is NO CELL PHONE SIGNAL once you've entered the museum!

RULES:

1. Food is not allowed in the museum except in the cafeteria. If you need to eat, make sure it's ONLY in the cafeteria! They are very strict about cleanliness in the museum! If you bring in like bottle of water or bag of chips, put it in your backpack until you get in the cafeteria. If you walk in with open bag of chips, or sandwich, or unfinished soda can, or a cup of coffee is unacceptable! If you have food on you which already eating, make sure to finish it before heading inside.

2. DO NOT mess around with the old trains! Such as scratching them, vandalizing or picking up the wicker seats!(Someone did that the last time and I wasn't happy about it!) You'll get in deep trouble for doing that! Some of the trains are 80 to over 100 years old. Please show some respect to them! If you don't respect the Museum trains, and the rules here, then I'll have to ask you to leave(I'm not joking. Rules are very strict in the museum). In this meetup is all about having fun and hanging out with your friends, not causing a raucous.

3. Filming and taking pictures is allowed.

4. No climbing on display objects!

5. Don't Litter.

6. It's the weekend, there will be a lot of children in the museum. So be careful!

7. NO! DO NOT GO ON TO THE TRACKS! They're electrified to keep the lights on the trains going.

Note: You must RSVP before you show up and also part of the group! No exceptions!  

How to get there:
Borough Hall (2,3,4 trains) is the nearby station from the museum. When you get out of the subway station, walk south on Boerum Pl. It's just two short blocks of walking.

Hours:

Tuesday – Friday 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.
Saturday and Sunday 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.
Closed Mondays and major holidays

results.description:
What better way to enjoy this great weather than a Saturday afternoon Picnic in Central Park. This is an annual tradition and like Diwali and Holi, we have a Picnic in Central Park every summer.


I will be getting professional catering done, there will be non alcoholic beverages, munchies including samosas, hummus, nachos and a few more items.

I would have to ask members to pitch in $10 to help me cover the cost of the food.

Alcohol is prohibited by law in Central Park, but as long as people aren't conspicuous or obnoxious, they usually don't get hassled :)

Bring a sheet to lay on, if you can. Games too. Feel free to bring a Frisbee or other fun activity to share/play with others like Frisbee, soccer ball etc

Directions

Enter the park at Central Park West and 67th St. Follow that walkway in, cross West Drive (with all the joggers and bikers heading south). Across that road is the Sheep Meadow.

I shall put a red flag, so look for it and that will be our group :)

See you all soon.
results.name: Funday In Central Park

results.description:
Hello Loyal Cowboy Fans,

Great wins and tough losses!  That categorizes our season so far, being 2-0 while losing some of our greatest weapons.

But if you are a Die Hard Dallas Fan, then you will show your belief in our Boys by joining us on Sunday when we take on the Falcons.  There's lots going on in NYC but Stone Creek will be THE place for watching THIS game.  Get there early, enjoy the food-the drink-the conversation, and let's cheer America's Team to another victory!

If you have any questions about this great group of fans, please feel free to e-mail me at [masked].

Hope to see you there!

Tave - CFFL (Cowboy Fan For Life)

results.description:
This Event:


The aim of this weekly event is to offer a place where fellow Python developers and learners can come and asks questions and/or code with some company! This event is free. 


Resources:

Here are some learning resources and free text editor / IDE suggestions.

https://github.com/logston/NYCPythonSOH/blob/master/resources.rst 

Detailed Directions to us:

As you enter the building located at 568 Broadway, New York, NY 10012 you will need to provide ID and your destination (Fueled Collective, 11th Floor) to the front desk. They will provide you with a sticker badge. Take one of the elevators (located to the right of the front desk) to the 11th floor. We will be in the Deerbrook conference room.

results.description:
September 27, 2015

Charms, Talismans and Amulets - A Hands on Approach

The Many Types How does it relate to Witchcraft How do we use them Creating them The Meanings behind them Working with them wisely Spell Casting $25 in person/$27 via paypal - If you paid online PLEASE bring your receipt to class.

If you have any issues, please call http://www.meetup.com/CharmedByStarrWitchesofNewYork/events/220058881/chrome-extension:/lifbcibllhkdhoafpjfnlhfpfgnpldfl/call_skype_logo.png917-378-5012

WFT Academy of Pagan Studies (WFTAPS) offers the most comprehensive, well-planned and affordable training available anywhere. We have a very interactive community based program. We provide many sources of learning that go into each and every class, which surpasses others when learning about Wicca / WitchCraft in New York City. We offer First through Third Degree training. Additionally we have many other Witch Crafting Classes & Workshops including: Herbal Intensive Series, Making A BOS, Tarot Classes, Besom Making, Candle SpellCrafting and much more.
What is wonderfully unique about WFT Academy of Pagan Studies is that it allows you to set the pace of your learning experience and provides you with an affordable way to grow within a structured Wiccan learning environment. You will be challenged and we do invite those who welcome this challenge to our Academy. We take your education very seriously, and in turn you should be serious about your education and training in the Path of Wicca / WitchCraft. Before considering enrollment and training at WFT Academy of Pagan Studies keep in mind that it is a life-path commitment.
Within our Academy there is an enormous amount of Community Interaction through the use of meetups, myspace, groups and now NEW! launching in 2013 online classes which will have our newly formed blog and forum etc., further enabling you to increase your knowledge and learning as well as providing you the ability to network with other like-minded individuals in a safe and supportive environment. Students can join this blog as long as they have registered at WFTAPS for classes
The Academy is truly a Spiritual Home and we welcome you to make it your own!
We have Degree-specific Study to discuss challenging lessons, facilitate rituals celebrating the Sabbats and Esbats as well as for healing and self-empowerment, all in a friendly and open atmosphere. We also hold Wiccan Degree dedications marking the stages of your training as you move through the Academy. We have found that many of our Students find it wonderful to be in a group learning environment that they can consider a Community Home.
We are all very proud of our Academy and what we have accomplished thus far. But ever mindful that it is each and every one of the Students that make it what it is. If you are reading this, we are confident that you would make a wonderful addition to our Academy and do hope that after reading this, you will decide to join us as at the Academy as a Student and member of The Wiccan Family Temple.
We welcome you to begin your studies by going to our ADMISSION AND PRICES (where you will find applications) page and submit your enrollment to the Academy today. We look forward to having you join us as a new Student of the WFT Academy of Pagan Studies.

WE ARE ALWAYS IMPROVING UPON WHAT WE OFFER STRIVING AND PROMISING TO ALWAYS KEEP RAISING THE BAR ON WHAT WE OFFER.

FOR MORE INFORMATION ON CLASSES, EVENTS ETC. PLEASE VISIT US AT:
www.wftacademyofpaganstudies.webs.com
www.wiccanfamilytemple.org
www.thenycpagancouncil.webs.com
www.romanctichandfastings.webs.com
www.charmedbystarr.com for all your ritual and pagan items.
results.name: Wicca Studies Classes 1st Degree
